name: TiKV
description: Distributed transactional key-value database, originally created to complement TiDB
description_good_justification: Front page of https://tikv.org/, also on our "Concepts" page" https://tikv.org/docs/
interact_justification: The website has a prominent "Github" button in the top right. There users can clone, report issues, and contribute.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/tikv/tikv/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/tikv/tikv/blob/master/LICENSE>.

floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).

documentation_interface_justification: A website (https://tikv.org/docs/) provides various operating and usage instructions. There are open source clients for 4 languages in various stages of stability at https://tikv.org/docs/3.0/reference/clients/introduction/, as well as public proto files.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub (https://github.com/tikv/tikv), which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Full history on Github in the Pull Requests section.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/tikv/tikv/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
build_floss_tools_justification: There are no proprietary or closed source tools required.
test_policy_justification: Contribution flow clearly states to include tests https://github.com/tikv/tikv/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#contribution-flow
warnings_justification: CI Uses rustfmt, Rust's 'clippy' and the normal Rustc linters.
warnings_strict_justification: Most warnings are enabled on clippy, but some are disabled because they have bugs or restrict functionality needed.
crypto_published_justification: Supported TLS system for transport layer security,
crypto_call_justification: TiKV depends on OpenSSL and the Rust crypto libraries.
crypto_keylength_justification: Any key length is supported, user provided certificates.
crypto_working_justification: The TiKV coprocessor contains some cryptographic functionality necessary for interoperability (Query layers such as TiDB implement protocols which may allow users to access these algorithms)
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The TiKV coprocessor contains some cryptographic functionality necessary for interoperability (Query layers such as TiDB implement protocols which may allow users to access these algorithms)
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.

name: LinuxTV
description:
The LinuxTV community develops and maintains the Linux Kernel Media Subsystems and several userspace libraries and applications.

The Linux Kernel Media Subsystems provide support for devices like webcams, streaming capture and output, analog TV, digital TV, AM/FM radio, Sofware Digital Radio (SDR), remote controllers and encoders/decoders for compressed video formats. It offers native support for a large number of drivers for commonly available PCI cards and USB devices, but the subsystems are also targeted towards Linux based set-top-boxes and embedded devices like mobile phones. 

The main goal is to develop the Linux Kernel media subsystem.

We also develop a series of userspace applications, tools and libraries: v4l-utils, ZBar, Kaffeine, XawTv, TVtime, Camorama, EDID decode, Digital TV tables. While several applications are used primarely by end users, for the developers of the project, their primary goal is to be able to test the Kernel development and to provide userspace libraries to enhance the media subsystem support.
description_good_justification: Project goals is clearly at the main page; each git tree we host have their own short descriptions. We maintain a Wiki page with all project details.
interact_justification:
The wiki pages have a developer's section explaining it: https://linuxtv.org/wiki/index.php/Developer_section
There are also ReST documentation at the Kernel tree with the Linux Kernel documentation, with applies to all the Kernel development, including the media subsystem.
contribution_justification:
The contribution process is explained at https://linuxtv.org/wiki/index.php/Developer_section
This project doesn't use GitHub. Instead, discussions, patches and pull requests goes via a mailing list (linux-media@vger.kernel.org), for all trees we host (both kernelspace and userspace).
contribution_requirements_justification:
We adopt Kernel coding style: https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/Documentation/SubmittingPatches
That's also  described at the Wiki.
license_location_justification: At libraries/tools, license is at COPYING files; at the Linux Kernel, the COPYING file points to the location of the SPDX licenses that apply:  https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/COPYING.
floss_license_justification: GPL-2.0-only The GPL-2.0-only license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The main license we use is GPL-2.0-only for the Linux Kernel. Userspace libraries and tools developed by the project are under LGPL and GPL. Some documentation are under GFDL with no invariant sections. Both GPL and LGPL are approved OSS licenses. The GPL-2.0-only license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: There is a comprehensive set of documentation at: https://linuxtv.org/docs.php
documentation_interface_justification: There is a comprehensive set of documentation at: https://linuxtv.org/docs.php
repo_public_justification: We use Git for all sub-projects.
repo_track_justification: We use Git for all sub-projects.
repo_interim_justification: Development is continuous using git. Patches contain incremental changes.
repo_distributed_justification: We use Git for all sub-projects.
version_semver_justification: Most of the trees we use use SemVer. Linux Kernel doesn't use, neither does XawTv, due to historical reasons.
version_tags_justification: We have tags for every release stored at the git repository.
release_notes_justification:
Kernel community maintain release notes on separate sites, like lwn.net and kernel-newbies: https://kernelnewbies.org/LinuxVersions

On other sub-projects, we maintain a ChangeLog file summarizing the changes.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Kernel CVE are propely documented. For other sub-projects, we never got a CVE assignment.
report_tracker_justification: For the Kernel, we use: https://bugzilla.kernel.org. Other sub-projects use GitHub; Kaffeine uses http://bugs.kde.org/.
report_process_justification: Bugs are submitted via mailing list: linux-media@vger.kernel.org: http://vger.kernel.org/vger-lists.html#linux-media
report_responses_justification: We answer to bug reports via mailing list.
enhancement_responses_justification: We accept enhancements in the form of patches submitted by interested parties. As this is related to hardware, and the number of media hardware is pretty big, enhancement development require developers to have the specific hardware in hands. We are not able to acquire all hardware we would need for hardware-specific development.
report_archive_justification:
There are several mirrors for the mailing lists. The main one is at: https://lore.kernel.org/linux-media/
we also maintain logs for the IRC channel discussions.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The only vulnerabilities we ever got are related to the Kernel. There's a documented process about reporting security issues to the Linux Kernel: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/security-bugs.html
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: The only vulnerabilities we ever got are related to the Kernel. There's a documented process about reporting security issues to the Linux Kernel: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/security-bugs.html
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Most of the time, we don't receive any vulnerability to the media subsystem. Last year, we got only one CVE and one private report at the beginning of 2018. Once we received the reports, they were promptly solved.
build_justification: Kernel just uses standard Makefiles; other projects use cmake or autotools.
build_common_tools_justification: Kernel just uses standard Makefiles; other projects use cmake or autotools.
build_floss_tools_justification: Everything is buildable with standard FLOSS tools like GNU c and glibc. No need to use proprietary build tools.
test_justification:
The Linux Kernel has several CI tools. One of them is at: https://kernelci.org/
We also have apps to check the compliance with hardware drivers with media APIs. We're in the process of adding CI for other sub-projects.
test_invocation_justification: As most of the stuff is hardware-dependent, there's no way to implement unit tests. So, we designed a test suite to check if the Kernel drivers are properly implementing the media APIs. The main tool is v4l2-compliance. We also provide a set of other tools in order to test the hardware.
test_most_justification: As most of the stuff is hardware-dependent, there's no way to implement unit tests. So, we designed a test suite to check if the Kernel drivers are properly implementing the media APIs. The main tool is v4l2-compliance. We also provide a set of other tools in order to test the hardware.
tests_are_added_justification: New drivers are required to pass at the compliance tools. The results of the tests should be submitted together with the patchsets adding the drivers.
warnings_justification: We have low tolerance to warnings at the project. Besides compiler warnings, we also test the Kernel multimedia subsystem with Coverity, Sparse and Smatch static code analyzers.
warnings_fixed_justification: Our goal is to have zero warnings when the media subsystem is built with W=1 (with enables lots of additional warnings over the usual Kernel standard).
warnings_strict_justification: We follow the Kernel policies. On distros, usually all warnings produce errors. At the Linux Kernel, this is an optional build feature.
know_secure_design_justification: The project main maintainer has CISSP certification (https://www.isc2.org/Certifications/CISSP).
know_common_errors_justification: The project main maintainer has CISSP certification (https://www.isc2.org/Certifications/CISSP).
crypto_published_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project. The website are https only.
crypto_call_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_floss_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project. The DVB API supports access to DVB CI hardware modules (with are meant to implement cryptography), but the implementation is out of the scope of the project, as we just enable access to the hardware cryptographic functions.
crypto_keylength_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_working_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_pfs_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_password_storage_justification: Only Camorama sub-project may allow the user to optionally store passwords, but this is done via standard Glib authentication mechanism. Nothing is stored directly by it.
crypto_random_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project nor depend on random number generator.
delivery_mitm_justification: Only camorama may use URLs to store camera images on a remote place. The mechanism supports https and scp.
delivery_unsigned_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project. The website we use is https only.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: We speed up fixes for critical vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The tools we use check for common vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Our goal is to have zero warnings from static code analyzers and compiler warnings (except for false-positive ones).
static_analysis_often_justification: We run sparse and smatch for every single commit applied to the tree.
dynamic_analysis_justification: https://01.org/lkp/documentation/0-day-test-service runs lots of these tools on all trees before release.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We don't run directly any fuzzer, but there are a group of Kernel developers doing that and doing periodic reports to our channels.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
Look at all of the wonderful BUG_ON() calls in the kernel (hint, you really don't want those to ever trigger, but they are there...)
Outside the Kernel, errors are properly handled by the library and tools, reporting runtime errors or using assert() calls.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We actively monitor reports from Kernel fuzzer projects and address them.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio:
The Linux Kernel has several CI tools. One of them is at: https://kernelci.org/
We also have apps to check the compliance with hardware drivers with media APIs. We're in the process of adding CI for other sub-projects.
discussion_justification: Most discussions happen at the open public mailing list (linux-media@vger.kernel.org). We also maintain #v4l and #linuxtv channels at irc.freenode.net.
no_leaked_credentials_justification:
We do our best efforts to keep private data confidential. We also have a privacy policy implemented:
https://linuxtv.org/wiki/index.php/LinuxTVWiki:Privacy_policy
english_justification: English is the preferred language, used on our channels.
hardening_justification:
The Linux kernel self protection project develops hardening improvements for the Linux kernel; many of them have already been accepted into the Linux kernel mainline: http://kernsec.org/wiki/index.php/Kernel_Self_Protection_Project There are a number of hardening mechanisms in the Linux kernel, such as Linux kernel stack protection.
For userspace tools, that doesn't apply, as priviledged permission is not required.
crypto_used_network_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_tls12_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Many third parties provide packages (e.g., .deb for apt-get, .rpm). We also store compressed tarballs at https://linuxtv.org/downloads for the source code userspace components. The install steps are described at the top level directory at README and INSTALL files (or README.md/INSTALL.md).
dco_justification:
https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/process/submitting-patches.html#sign-your-work-the-developer-s-certificate-of-origin 
We also maintain a copy of it on our Wiki.
governance_justification: For the Kernel: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/process/development-process.html. A similar development process is used for userspace tools.
roles_responsibilities_justification: For the Kernel: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/process/development-process.html. A similar development process is used for userspace tools.
access_continuity_justification: For the Kernel: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/process/development-process.html. A similar development process is used for userspace tools.
documentation_roadmap_justification: There is never a roadmap for the kernel, this type of thing is crazy for a project to try to determine. If you want to see what is coming, look at https://git.kernel.org/. We do have at least one Media Summit per year where we discuss the subsystem's evolution. The results of the summits are at https://linuxtv.org/news.php.
documentation_architecture_justification: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/process/development-process.html. The media architecture itself is described at: https://linuxtv.org/docs.php.
documentation_achievements_justification: We keep all trees at https://git.linuxtv.org. They contain all achievements.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: The focus of the project is to provide support for video streaming.  Yet, Digital TV API and userspace apps support captions, allowing impared hearing people to watch video. Also, it supports multiple audio channels including narration ones, allowing people with visual disabilities to be able to watch TV.
internationalization_justification: The project use i8n technologies on userspace tools in order to allow multiple language translations. Several language translations are provided.
sites_password_security_justification: Passwords are stored only for wiki. Twiki stores them encrypted.
maintenance_or_update_justification: We maintain a ports tree that allows usind new drivers with older Kernels.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: We use Reported-by: tags to indicate contributions. Those are stored at the git trees: https://git.linuxtv.org/
coding_standards_enforced_justification: scripts/checkpatch.pl checks and enforces coding style rules.
build_standard_variables_justification: All build environment variables are properly handled.
build_preserve_debug_justification: For the Kernel, configuration options allow for all debugging symbols to be retained in the built objects. For userspace apps/libraries, the building system honours LDFLAGS.
build_non_recursive_justification: No recursion in the build system when there are cross-dependencies in the subdirectories.
build_repeatable_justification: The project meets the reproducible build requirements.
installation_standard_variables_justific: It uses standard tools that honors things like DESTDIR.
installation_development_quick_justifica: At Kernel, all distros usually have a 'kernel-developer' meta-package option to automatically install needed dependancies to build the project. On userspace, "make install" install all compiled components.
external_dependencies_justification: This applies only for userspace. We don't maintain a per-distribution parseable list of components upstream, as this is distro-dependent, but this is easily obtained within the distributions.
dependency_monitoring_justification:
The kernel has no external dependencies.
No media apps require priviledged (root) access.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: All efforts are made to avoid non-standard components.
interfaces_current_justification: All efforts are made to keep the projects updated to the latest versions of the libraries it uses.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: It is not possible to automate tests for hardware-dependent components. We're adding automation to the media core function by using virtual drivers that emulate a real hardware. For the Linux Kernel, the 0-day bot runs on each commit in almost all maintainers trees before they are merged into Linus's tree.
regression_tests_added50_justification:
It is impossible to create automated regression tests for even a small percentage of the bugs found in the kernel. It is even harder for parts that depend having an specific hardware. 
Yet, people are actively working on this, and we do have a very large test suite that includes checks for almost all major CVEs that can be tested for.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Code coverage is a horrible metric, specially for hardware-dependent software components. See above for the discussion about our automated regression tests.
test_policy_mandated_justification: Not all new features are able to have automated tests added for them. Yet, there are compliance tools and it is a requirement that developers should run them before submitting new drivers.
implement_secure_design_justification: The kernel and userspace tools implement "known secure design" principles.
input_validation_justification: Only valid users can push things at the git trees, using cryptographic keys.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: We don't implement cryptography at the project.
signed_releases_justification: For the Linux Kernel, all tags for kernel releases are properly signed. We also sign tags on userspace tools. For all download source code, we maintain sha1sum and sha512sum.
version_tags_signed_justification: For the Linux Kernel, all tags for kernel releases are properly signed. We also sign tags on userspace tools
assurance_case_justification: We have it only for the Linux Kernel. The kernel's security requirements are constantly tested and probed by everyone in the world. When problems are found, they are resolved as quickly as possible as described in our security bugs reporting documentation: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/security-bugs.html

The docs included in the repo contains information at various levels: the design, principles, purposes of the app.
It also contains user manuals for significant portions of the app, e.g. the query language. There are references to a big family of tutorials in the tutorials repository under the same Github organization.

build_justification:
There is a build script that performs all possible building tasks: 
https://github.com/annotation/text-fabric/blob/master/build.py
build_common_tools_justification: There is very little that has to be built: the Python scripts and Javascripts do not need to be built before shipping.

The principle build tool, build.py is a python script, using only open source python libraries.
https://github.com/annotation/text-fabric/blob/master/build.py
test_invocation_justification:
Via the build.py script, which is Python. It uses a Python library for (unit)-testing.
https://github.com/annotation/text-fabric/blob/master/build.py
test_most_justification:
Only some very tricky bits of functionality are rigorously tested: the basic spatial relationships in a textual corpus: 
https://annotation.github.io/text-fabric/Use/Search/#relational-operators
test_policy_justification: New functionality is very diverse. Impossible to formulate a policy for that. That will change if the project matures.
tests_are_added_justification: We do not have that test policy in place.
tests_documented_added_justification: We do not have that test policy in place.
warnings_justification:
We use linters and formatters for both Python and Javascript: 
https://github.com/annotation/text-fabric/blob/master/codestyle/contributing.md
warnings_fixed_justification: All code is required to pass all linters, although it is not enforced.
crypto_published_justification: The software is about ancient texts and annotations and tries to make that data as open as possible. We do not deal with private data and workflows where personal data is at stake. We do not use copyrighted material.
crypto_call_justification: The software is about ancient texts and annotations and tries to make that data as open as possible. We do not deal with private data and workflows where personal data is at stake. We do not use copyrighted material.

maintained_justification: I have a mandate to keep Text-Fabric live. Researchers are using it. The institute that employs me, mentions it on its website: https://dans.knaw.nl/en/data-expertise/ (scroll down to the section **Tools**).

name: java-html-sanitizer
description: Takes third-party HTML and produces HTML that is safe to embed in your web application.  Fast and easy to configure.
sites_https_justification:
Given only https: URLs.

Github hosts the markdown documentation via https.
javadoc.io hosts documentation generated from source via https.
Download information is available from maven central via https.
description_good_justification:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/README.md says

"A fast and easy to configure HTML Sanitizer written in Java which lets you include HTML authored by third-parties in your web application while protecting against XSS."
interact_justification:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/README.md says

"Subscribe to the mailing list to be notified of known Vulnerabilities. If you wish to report a vulnerability, please see AttackReviewGroundRules."
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/COPYING>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/docs/getting_started.md provides "getting started" documentation that points to generated JavaDoc which explain the core APIs in detail.  For example:

https://static.javadoc.io/com.googlecode.owasp-java-html-sanitizer/owasp-java-html-sanitizer/20181114.1/org/owasp/html/HtmlPolicyBuilder.html

The project includes example policies which users have successfully tailored to their needs.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification:
Releases are tagged in Github.  See https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/tags
Historical releases available at https://search.maven.org/artifact/com.googlecode.owasp-java-html-sanitizer/owasp-java-html-sanitizer/20181114.1/jar

Release process is documented at https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/RELEASE-checklist.sh
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/RELEASE-checklist.sh explains how version numbers are obtained.

They are monotonic but unfortunately not semver :(
version_semver_justification: The project started using YYYY.MM.DD.SERIAL fairly early on.  Unfortunately, changing that might adversely affect existing clients.
report_process_justification:
The maintainer monitors the Github issue tracker.
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/issues
report_responses_justification: https://github.com/owasp/java-html-sanitizer/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+created%3A%3E%3D2018-04-20+ indicates that of 18 issues raised in the last 12 months (relative to 20 Apr 2019) all were responded to.
enhancement_responses_justification: https://github.com/owasp/java-html-sanitizer/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue+created%3A%3E%3D2018-04-20+ shows 4 enhancement requests in the last 12 months all of which were responded to.
report_archive_justification:
All non-security issues available at https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue

Security reports found to be actionable summarized at https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/docs/vulnerabilities.md

Non-actionable security reports are stored in https://bugcrowd.com/owaspjavasanitizer but are not public.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Both the README and the issue report template point to https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/docs/attack_review_ground_rules.md which provides some background before pointing reporters to https://bugcrowd.com/owaspjavasanitizer
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: OWASP uses https://bugcrowd.com/owaspjavasanitizer to track reporting and bounties for this project.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: I believe I have never taken longer than 72 hours to respond to a report and provide a patch for the actionable ones.
build_common_tools_justification:
Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/pom.xml>.

Maven is pretty standard for Java libraries.
build_floss_tools_justification:
Maven is open-source.  Ancillary tools like bash and GPG are open-source.
There are open-source Java compilers that are compatible with the source code and the .travis.yml file uses checks that the project builds on several openjdk versions: https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/ea101ceb2d68a990f87e5ec88337e27569be7515/.travis.yml#L5-L6
test_justification:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/tree/master/src/test/java/org/owasp/html has most of the test files.

It includes unit tests which due to the nature of the project are heavily tilted towards negative tests, and a number of hand-crafted fuzzers to suss out crashing issues:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/src/test/java/org/owasp/html/HtmlSanitizerFuzzerTest.java
test_invocation_justification: `mvn verify` is idiomatic for this kind of project and works as expected.
test_most_justification:
`mvn test site` generates a jacoco coverage report at target/site/jacoco/index.html.  Below is the summary:

Element	Missed Instructions	Cov.	Missed Branches	Cov.	Missed	Cxty	Missed	Lines	Missed	Methods	Missed	Classes
Total	1,853 of 33,163	94%	431 of 2,404	82%	398	1,710	337	4,120	64	462	0	85

As part of this process, added build machinery to capture historical rates at https://coveralls.io/github/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer?branch=master
test_policy_justification: This has been the policy but has not been documented.
tests_are_added_justification: https://gist.github.com/mikesamuel/8b16a0de692b77171cf38825b2f4f601 shows that 71.42% of the commits in the last 20 that touch source files also touch test files.  Some of the ones that do not are comment only changes but I have not attempted to filter those out.
warnings_justification: In addition to an aggressive set of IDE warnings, https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/ea101ceb2d68a990f87e5ec88337e27569be7515/parent/pom.xml#L69-L87
warnings_fixed_justification:
All IDE warnings and issues are addressed.

`mvn compile site` generates a report that has 1 low priority issue and 2 medium priority issues.
The reasons for all these are documented.   2 are related to supporting multiple versions of Java & Guava.  1 is a dead store that is considered less bad than the maintenance hazard of not keeping the variably nominally consistent.
warnings_strict_justification:
`mvn compile site` generates an analysis report that includes

FindBugs Version is 3.0.1
Threshold is low
Effort is max

https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/95d89afa17d704b3dc044b76909579a2af2a5aae/parent/pom.xml#L76-L85
know_secure_design_justification:
I am the primary developer, am a security engineering professional, and am published in my field.

http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.306.6704
http://webblaze.cs.berkeley.edu/csas.html
know_common_errors_justification: The primary author has worked on similar systems used in high profile projects like Gmail.
crypto_published_justification: No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.
crypto_call_justification: No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.
crypto_floss_justification: No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.
crypto_keylength_justification: No cryptography is used therefore there it is technically true that "there is no key length in this project that is shorter than a key length used by any other project ever."
crypto_working_justification: No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.
crypto_pfs_justification: No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.
crypto_password_storage_justification:
This project does that.

It is possible that a very odd configuration might allow an `<input type=password>` to make it from input through to output but those would neither be "stored" nor "for authentication of external users."
crypto_random_justification:
No secrets are generated and the use of PRNGs is restricted to test code (see fuzzers).
I believe the static analysis done on `mvn verify` would detect uses of java.util.Random instead of java.util.SecureRandom outside test code but have not tested.
delivery_mitm_justification: This sends no network messages.  It is a string to string transform.
delivery_unsigned_justification: This project does no cryptography.  It is a string to string transform.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: The bugcrowd queue is clear and has been.  I get a few reports a year and respond promptly.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: I believe I have done this and intend to continue.
static_analysis_justification: `mvn compile site` generates target/site/findbugs.html which is run and checked as part of the release checklist.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j:
Error prone provides these bug patterns https://errorprone.info/bugpatterns
The maven file does not turn any off that are on by default, so patterns like https://errorprone.info/bugpattern/InsecureCryptoUsage would surface uses of deprecated crypto APIs.
static_analysis_fixed_justification:
The IDE configured checker produces no warnings or errors.

`mvn compile site` generates a report that has 1 low priority issue and 2 medium priority issues.
The reasons for all these are documented.   2 are related to supporting multiple versions of Java & Guava.  1 is a dead store that is considered less bad than the maintenance hazard of not keeping the variably nominally consistent.
static_analysis_often_justification: It runs every commit as part of the `mvn verify` calls ( https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/ea101ceb2d68a990f87e5ec88337e27569be7515/scripts/build_for_travis.sh#L13-L17 ) that is kicked off by .travis.yml.
dynamic_analysis_justification:
The code was developed alongside fuzzers crafted for this particular product.

See *FuzzerTest.java in https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/tree/master/src/test/java/org/owasp/html

Thanks for the pointer.  I may reach out to OSS-Fuzz for additional assurance.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: Code is in Java and includes no methods marked with keyword native.  The only runtime dependency is Guava so the native method surface is small.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi:
For example, the serializer is security sensitive so includes assertions about its output.
See https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/ea101ceb2d68a990f87e5ec88337e27569be7515/src/main/java/org/owasp/html/HtmlStreamRenderer.java#L289 which is a runtime assertion that checks that the output will parse to the same structure.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: This is a library and it does not phone home with telemetry but we follow up on issues that include reports of runtime errors due to assertion failures.
crypto_weaknesses_justification:
No cryptography is used.  This is a string to string transform.

Full disclosure: This project depends on common tools like git which use SHA-1 internally and which cannot currently be configured to do otherwise.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: This library accepts no credentials, sends no network messages, nor IPC, and provides hooks to enable logging but does not log any inputs itself.
english_justification:
All documentation is available in English.

Documentation for filing issues and reporting security issues is available in English:
https://github.com/OWASP/java-html-sanitizer/blob/master/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

name: Vulnerability assessment tool
description: Analyses Java and Python applications for open-source dependencies with known vulnerabilities, using both static analysis and testing to determine code context and usage for greater accuracy.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/blob/master/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/user/
documentation_interface_justification:
A Swagger definition and a Javadoc can be generated while spinning up a backend server. But it is not yet provided as part of the documentation for the end-users.
Input for Gradle plugin: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/user/manuals/setup/#gradle
Input for Maven plugin: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/user/manuals/setup/#maven
Input for CLI: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/user/manuals/setup/#maven
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification:
https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/releases
Including description for Bug Fixes, Improvements, Features, Breaking Changes
report_process_justification:
Read https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#report-an-issue, then open an issue or a StackOverflow question.

https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/issues/new/choose
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vulas
report_responses_justification: All issues are acknowledged and tried to be fixed with major priority
enhancement_responses_justification: All requests are and were answered
build_justification:
Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/blob/master/pom.xml>.
Docs' build process: https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/tree/master/docs
Easy docker setup process: https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/tree/master/docker and https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/admin/
build_common_tools_justification:
Non-trivial build file in repository: <https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/blob/master/pom.xml>.

Maven is used to build the Java core components. Docker to build the test containers. Python to build the documentation.
test_policy_justification: Tests of new functionalities are informally asked for new tests to be added. Core contributors add tests.
tests_are_added_justification: New features are asked to be tested
warnings_justification: Maven automatically checks the code for compilable Java code.
warnings_strict_justification: `showWarnings` flag is not enabled in Maven.
know_secure_design_justification: All the five main contributors of vulnerability-assessment-tool are also security engineers
know_common_errors_justification: All the five main contributors of vulnerability-assessment-tool have a vast knowledge of the Java language and the related kinds of errors that lead to vulnerabilities.
crypto_keylength_justification: The core logic of the application does not encrypt anything on his own.
crypto_password_storage_justification: No passwords are stored. No concept of username/password is present in vulnerability-assessment-tool
delivery_mitm_justification: client-server connections happen at only HTTPS level.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: SHA1 algorithm is only used for identifying entities of various kind and not for security reasons
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Travis is used to build and test the Java core application. To build test Docker containers. TO check if the documentation is buildable and if there are dead links.
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/issues
https://github.com/SAP/vulnerability-assessment-tool/pulls
english_justification:
Docs for using vulnerability-assessment-tool: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/user/
Docs for deploying vulnerability-assessment-tool: https://sap.github.io/vulnerability-assessment-tool/admin/
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
implementation_languages: Java, JavaScript, Python, ANTLR, Shell, Dockerfile, Groovy, PLpgSQL

name: Subsurface
description: Subsurface can plan and track single- and multi-tank dives using air, Nitrox or TriMix. It allows tracking of dive locations including GPS coordinates (which can also conveniently be entered using a map interface), logging of equipment used and names of other divers, and lets users rate dives and provide additional notes. It runs on Windows, macOS, and Linux, the mobile flavor Subsurface-mobile, built from the same source repo, runs on Android and iOS.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification: The application doesn't provide APIs / external interfaces
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Every commit to the project is posted to the public repo. We do not engage in commit squashing. Typically hundreds of commits between releases.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification:
Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
This file is used to collect the changes since the last release.
Complete log is in https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/blob/master/ReleaseNotes/ReleaseNotes.txt
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no vulnerabilities with CVE assignment
report_process_justification:
https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/issues
also by sending bugs to either our user forum https://subsurface-divelog.org/user-forum/ or our mailing list subsurface@subsurface-divelog.org
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: There is no private process to report vulnerabilities
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: No vulnerabilities have been reported in the last 6 months
test_justification:
Travis testing is included in the repo.
Unit tests are in https://github.com/Subsurface-divelog/subsurface/tree/master/tests
test_most_justification: The test suite is typically updated after we find bugs or as we make significant changes. But large parts of the code are not covered by tests at all.
test_policy_justification: We have this policy but are not enforcing it
crypto_pfs_justification:
We have whitelisted the SSL key for one of the backend services directly in source code - with no mechanism to revoke it.
That key will expire later this year and the corresponding code will be removed.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The concept of "external user" isn't applicable
static_analysis_justification: LGTM.com is integrated into our PR review process and therefore run prior to releases as well
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: the git repo contains an intentionally public id/password pair that can be used for testing the cloud storage service
english_justification:
English is the default language of all communication.
On a best effort basis we allow bug reports in other languages (and have successfully engaged with users reporting issues in German, French, Dutch, and Spanish
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: C++, C, XSLT, QML, Shell, CMake, JavaScript, TeX, Perl, QMake, Makefile, Dockerfile, Java, Objective-C
